prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAM04191
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Multiplicity and Disks in IRAM04191 (d = 140 pc)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Two basebands will be used to measure the continuum, with the sensitivity justified above. A third baseband will be used to observe 12CO2-1 to detect and characterize outflows from multiple systems. We require a total bandwidth of ~150 km/s in order to detect the full velocity extent of outflows, which can extend up to 50-75 km/s from rest in the fastest outflows. This bandwidth gives us 75 km/s in the red and blue sides of the spectrum and guarantees full characterization of outflows. Since outflows extend over anywhere from 3-75 km/s, we use spectral averaging to reduce the spectral resolution to 0.3 km/s, which still gives at least 10 resolution elements per outflow, sufficient for accurate characterization of the mass and energy spectra of the outflows.
The last spectral window is used to observe 13CO and C18O. The total velocity extent of the Keplerian rotation traced by these lines will be confined within 3-4 km/s from rest, so the narrowest bandwidth (80 km/s) is chosen. We then use spectral averaging to obtain a velocity resolution of 0.1 km/s, which many studies have shown is adequate for characterizing Keplerian rotation (e.g., Lee et al. 2011, ApJ, 741, 62).
With this correlator setup our program will generate a modest data rate of 4.22 MB/s, thus there should be no concerns about high data rates.

The requested resolution of 0.14" corresponds to linear resolutions of 17-63 AU at the distances to our objects (125-450 pc). This particular resolution is chosen so that our survey reaches a 50% completeness limit of 30 AU, about two times smaller than the peak in the Perseus separation distribution of ~50 AU. This resolution is also required in order to identify resolved continuum structures indicative of protostellar disks, as such disks are typically <200 AU in size (and often <100 AU for the youngest Class 0 systems).
The largest angular scale is set to 2", corresponding to 250-900 AU for our objects with distances of 125-450 pc. This scale is set by the requirement of fully recovering disks even in the most nearby cores, since, as stated above, such disks are typically <200 AU in size.

Our sensitivity is driven by the continuum observations, as continuum detections of multiple protostars is the primary motivation for this proposal. In order to properly compare our results on isolated multiplicity to those in Perseus obtained by the large VLA VANDAM survey discussed in the proposal text, we must at least match their sensitivity. VANDAM achieved a 1sigma rms of 10 uJy at 8 mm. Scaling this up to 1.3 mm assuming beta=1 (implying a spectral index of 3) gives 2.3 mJy. However, the 8 mm VLA data is contaminated by free-free emission; using 4 and 6 cm data also obtained through VANDAM, we estimate a contamination rate of typically <50%, but occasionally as high as 90%. Assuming the worst case (90% contamination, meaning only 10% of the 8mm flux is from thermal dust continuum emission), we thus require a sensitivity of 0.1*2.3 mJy = 0.23 mJy for objects at the same distance as Perseus (230 pc). Thus our desired sensitivity is calculated as 0.23 mJy * (230 pc / d)^2, where d is the distance to the core(s) contained in each science goal. In other words, we integrate longer for more distant cores in order to maintain a uniform mass sensitivity.
With the integration time set by the continuum sensitivity, we will achieve 1sigma sensitivities of 26 mJy/beam * (230 pc / d)^2 for 12CO2-1 in 0.5 km/s channels, and 46 mJy/beam * (230 pc / d)^2 for 13CO and C18O 2-1 in 0.1 km/s channels. The 12CO and 13CO sensitivities are nearly identical (within 10%) of those obtained by Lee et al. (2011), ApJ, 741, 62 with the SMA, which they showed were sufficient to detect an outflow from and characterize Keplerian rotation around a very young Class I protostar.
For C18O, published ALMA cycle 0 and 1 observations suggest a 1sigma rms of 20-30 is required to guarantee sufficient S/N to characterize Keplerian rotation in Class 0 disks (e.g., Murillo et al. 2013, A&A), which often cannot be probed with 13CO. After smoothing to 0.2-0.3 km/s, which is still sufficient spectral resolution, we will meet these sensitivities. For many of the brighter targets smoothing will not be required. For some of the weakest targets we may not obtain sufficient S/N, but detection of Keplerian rotation is a secondary goal - the primary goal of characterizing multiplicity will be met with the continuum observations.
The peak flux densities and peak line fluxes entered into the OT are estimates of the lowest expected peak values and demonstrate that all sources of interest should be detectable by this survey.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BHR79
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Multiplicity and Disks in BHR79 (d = 150 pc)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Two basebands will be used to measure the continuum, with the sensitivity justified above. A third baseband will be used to observe 12CO2-1 to detect and characterize outflows from multiple systems. We require a total bandwidth of ~150 km/s in order to detect the full velocity extent of outflows, which can extend up to 50-75 km/s from rest in the fastest outflows. This bandwidth gives us 75 km/s in the red and blue sides of the spectrum and guarantees full characterization of outflows. Since outflows extend over anywhere from 3-75 km/s, we use spectral averaging to reduce the spectral resolution to 0.3 km/s, which still gives at least 10 resolution elements per outflow, sufficient for accurate characterization of the mass and energy spectra of the outflows.
The last spectral window is used to observe 13CO and C18O. The total velocity extent of the Keplerian rotation traced by these lines will be confined within 3-4 km/s from rest, so the narrowest bandwidth (80 km/s) is chosen. We then use spectral averaging to obtain a velocity resolution of 0.1 km/s, which many studies have shown is adequate for characterizing Keplerian rotation (e.g., Lee et al. 2011, ApJ, 741, 62).
With this correlator setup our program will generate a modest data rate of 4.22 MB/s, thus there should be no concerns about high data rates.

The requested resolution of 0.14" corresponds to linear resolutions of 17-63 AU at the distances to our objects (125-450 pc). This particular resolution is chosen so that our survey reaches a 50% completeness limit of 30 AU, about two times smaller than the peak in the Perseus separation distribution of ~50 AU. This resolution is also required in order to identify resolved continuum structures indicative of protostellar disks, as such disks are typically <200 AU in size (and often <100 AU for the youngest Class 0 systems).
The largest angular scale is set to 2", corresponding to 250-900 AU for our objects with distances of 125-450 pc. This scale is set by the requirement of fully recovering disks even in the most nearby cores, since, as stated above, such disks are typically <200 AU in size.

Our sensitivity is driven by the continuum observations, as continuum detections of multiple protostars is the primary motivation for this proposal. In order to properly compare our results on isolated multiplicity to those in Perseus obtained by the large VLA VANDAM survey discussed in the proposal text, we must at least match their sensitivity. VANDAM achieved a 1sigma rms of 10 uJy at 8 mm. Scaling this up to 1.3 mm assuming beta=1 (implying a spectral index of 3) gives 2.3 mJy. However, the 8 mm VLA data is contaminated by free-free emission; using 4 and 6 cm data also obtained through VANDAM, we estimate a contamination rate of typically <50%, but occasionally as high as 90%. Assuming the worst case (90% contamination, meaning only 10% of the 8mm flux is from thermal dust continuum emission), we thus require a sensitivity of 0.1*2.3 mJy = 0.23 mJy for objects at the same distance as Perseus (230 pc). Thus our desired sensitivity is calculated as 0.23 mJy * (230 pc / d)^2, where d is the distance to the core(s) contained in each science goal. In other words, we integrate longer for more distant cores in order to maintain a uniform mass sensitivity.
With the integration time set by the continuum sensitivity, we will achieve 1sigma sensitivities of 26 mJy/beam * (230 pc / d)^2 for 12CO2-1 in 0.5 km/s channels, and 46 mJy/beam * (230 pc / d)^2 for 13CO and C18O 2-1 in 0.1 km/s channels. The 12CO and 13CO sensitivities are nearly identical (within 10%) of those obtained by Lee et al. (2011), ApJ, 741, 62 with the SMA, which they showed were sufficient to detect an outflow from and characterize Keplerian rotation around a very young Class I protostar.
For C18O, published ALMA cycle 0 and 1 observations suggest a 1sigma rms of 20-30 is required to guarantee sufficient S/N to characterize Keplerian rotation in Class 0 disks (e.g., Murillo et al. 2013, A&A), which often cannot be probed with 13CO. After smoothing to 0.2-0.3 km/s, which is still sufficient spectral resolution, we will meet these sensitivities. For many of the brighter targets smoothing will not be required. For some of the weakest targets we may not obtain sufficient S/N, but detection of Keplerian rotation is a secondary goal - the primary goal of characterizing multiplicity will be met with the continuum observations.
The peak flux densities and peak line fluxes entered into the OT are estimates of the lowest expected peak values and demonstrate that all sources of interest should be detectable by this survey.

In other words, we integrate longer for more distant cores in order to maintain a uniform mass sensitivity.
With the integration time set by the continuum sensitivity, we will achieve 1sigma sensitivities of 26 mJy/beam * (230 pc / d)^2 for 12CO2-1 in 0.5 km/s channels, and 46 mJy/beam * (230 pc / d)^2 for 13CO and C18O 2-1 in 0.1 km/s channels. The 12CO and 13CO sensitivities are nearly identical (within 10%) of those obtained by Lee et al. (2011), ApJ, 741, 62 with the SMA, which they showed were sufficient to detect an outflow from and characterize Keplerian rotation around a very young Class I protostar.
For C18O, published ALMA cycle 0 and 1 observations suggest a 1sigma rms of 20-30 is required to guarantee sufficient S/N to characterize Keplerian rotation in Class 0 disks (e.g., Murillo et al. 2013, A&A), which often cannot be probed with 13CO. After smoothing to 0.2-0.3 km/s, which is still sufficient spectral resolution, we will meet these sensitivities. For many of the brighter targets smoothing will not be required. For some of the weakest targets we may not obtain sufficient S/N, but detection of Keplerian rotation is a secondary goal - the primary goal of characterizing multiplicity will be met with the continuum observations.
The peak flux densities and peak line fluxes entered into the OT are estimates of the lowest expected peak values and demonstrate that all sources of interest should be detectable by this survey.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CB170
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Multiplicity and Disks in CB170 (d = 270 pc)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Two basebands will be used to measure the continuum, with the sensitivity justified above. A third baseband will be used to observe 12CO2-1 to detect and characterize outflows from multiple systems. We require a total bandwidth of ~150 km/s in order to detect the full velocity extent of outflows, which can extend up to 50-75 km/s from rest in the fastest outflows. This bandwidth gives us 75 km/s in the red and blue sides of the spectrum and guarantees full characterization of outflows. Since outflows extend over anywhere from 3-75 km/s, we use spectral averaging to reduce the spectral resolution to 0.3 km/s, which still gives at least 10 resolution elements per outflow, sufficient for accurate characterization of the mass and energy spectra of the outflows.
The last spectral window is used to observe 13CO and C18O. The total velocity extent of the Keplerian rotation traced by these lines will be confined within 3-4 km/s from rest, so the narrowest bandwidth (80 km/s) is chosen. We then use spectral averaging to obtain a velocity resolution of 0.1 km/s, which many studies have shown is adequate for characterizing Keplerian rotation (e.g., Lee et al. 2011, ApJ, 741, 62).
With this correlator setup our program will generate a modest data rate of 4.22 MB/s, thus there should be no concerns about high data rates.

The requested resolution of 0.14" corresponds to linear resolutions of 17-63 AU at the distances to our objects (125-450 pc). This particular resolution is chosen so that our survey reaches a 50% completeness limit of 30 AU, about two times smaller than the peak in the Perseus separation distribution of ~50 AU. This resolution is also required in order to identify resolved continuum structures indicative of protostellar disks, as such disks are typically <200 AU in size (and often <100 AU for the youngest Class 0 systems).
The largest angular scale is set to 2", corresponding to 250-900 AU for our objects with distances of 125-450 pc. This scale is set by the requirement of fully recovering disks even in the most nearby cores, since, as stated above, such disks are typically <200 AU in size.

Our sensitivity is driven by the continuum observations, as continuum detections of multiple protostars is the primary motivation for this proposal. In order to properly compare our results on isolated multiplicity to those in Perseus obtained by the large VLA VANDAM survey discussed in the proposal text, we must at least match their sensitivity. VANDAM achieved a 1sigma rms of 10 uJy at 8 mm. Scaling this up to 1.3 mm assuming beta=1 (implying a spectral index of 3) gives 2.3 mJy. However, the 8 mm VLA data is contaminated by free-free emission; using 4 and 6 cm data also obtained through VANDAM, we estimate a contamination rate of typically <50%, but occasionally as high as 90%. Assuming the worst case (90% contamination, meaning only 10% of the 8mm flux is from thermal dust continuum emission), we thus require a sensitivity of 0.1*2.3 mJy = 0.23 mJy for objects at the same distance as Perseus (230 pc). Thus our desired sensitivity is calculated as 0.23 mJy * (230 pc / d)^2, where d is the distance to the core(s) contained in each science goal. In other words, we integrate longer for more distant cores in order to maintain a uniform mass sensitivity.
With the integration time set by the continuum sensitivity, we will achieve 1sigma sensitivities of 26 mJy/beam * (230 pc / d)^2 for 12CO2-1 in 0.5 km/s channels, and 46 mJy/beam * (230 pc / d)^2 for 13CO and C18O 2-1 in 0.1 km/s channels. The 12CO and 13CO sensitivities are nearly identical (within 10%) of those obtained by Lee et al. (2011), ApJ, 741, 62 with the SMA, which they showed were sufficient to detect an outflow from and characterize Keplerian rotation around a very young Class I protostar.
For C18O, published ALMA cycle 0 and 1 observations suggest a 1sigma rms of 20-30 is required to guarantee sufficient S/N to characterize Keplerian rotation in Class 0 disks (e.g., Murillo et al. 2013, A&A), which often cannot be probed with 13CO. After smoothing to 0.2-0.3 km/s, which is still sufficient spectral resolution, we will meet these sensitivities. For many of the brighter targets smoothing will not be required. For some of the weakest targets we may not obtain sufficient S/N, but detection of Keplerian rotation is a secondary goal - the primary goal of characterizing multiplicity will be met with the continuum observations.
The peak flux densities and peak line fluxes entered into the OT are estimates of the lowest expected peak values and demonstrate that all sources of interest should be detectable by this survey.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Multiple star systems are a common outcome of star formation. While the binary frequencies and separation distributions are well-characterized in the field, theoretical studies predict that the majority of multiple systems are formed very early in the protostellar phase and undergo significant and rapid dynamical evolution. Thus knowledge of the intrinsic multiplicity fraction and separation distribution before modification via dynamical evolution requires studying the youngest objects: Class 0 and I protostars still embedded in and accreting from their parent cores. Recent surveys have made great progress in characterizing protostellar multiplicity in clustered environments but have left unanswered a key question: is the fragmentation into multiple systems dependent on environment? Here we propose an ALMA band 6 multiplicity survey of 22 truly isolated protostellar cores down to approximately 30 AU resolution in order to measure the protostellar multiplicity fraction and separation distribution in isolated globules and determine the effects of environment on fragmentation.
